questions:
A 28-year-old intravenous drug user presents to your GP clinic: he is a frequent non-attender and you note he has been recently been discharged from hospital following a diagnosis of chronic hepatitis C.

Given his new diagnosis which vaccination does he now qualify for?
notes:
Those patients diagnosed with chronic hepatitis should be offered both the annual influenza vaccine and the pneumococcal vaccine, which is given one a one-off basis. The pneumococcal vaccine is only given on a one-off basis, as it is not a rapidly mutating condition, unlike influenza.

The hepatitis E vaccine is unavailable in the UK and the tetanus vaccine would only be indicated if he had sustained a high-risk wound. This patient does not meet the criteria for a BCG vaccine at this time.
question:
A 28-year-old intravenous drug user presents to your GP clinic: he is a frequent non-attender and you note he has been recently been discharged from hospital following a diagnosis of chronic hepatitis C.

Given his new diagnosis which vaccination does he now qualify for?
question_notes:
Those patients diagnosed with chronic hepatitis should be offered both the annual influenza vaccine and the pneumococcal vaccine, which is given one a one-off basis. The pneumococcal vaccine is only given on a one-off basis, as it is not a rapidly mutating condition, unlike influenza.

The hepatitis E vaccine is unavailable in the UK and the tetanus vaccine would only be indicated if he had sustained a high-risk wound. This patient does not meet the criteria for a BCG vaccine at this time.
title: Vaccinations in special groups
body:
The table below summarises the current Green Book advice regarding the influenza and pneumococcal vaccine.

Influenza vaccinationPneumococcal vaccination
The Department of Health recommends annual influenza vaccination for people older than 65 years and those with:
  • chronic respiratory disease (including asthmatics who use inhaled steroids)
  • chronic heart disease (heart failure, ischaemic heart disease, including hypertension if associated with cardiac complications)
  • chronic kidney disease (at stages 3, 4 or 5, chronic kidney failure, nephrotic syndrome, kidney transplantation)
  • chronic liver disease: cirrhosis, biliary atresia, chronic hepatitis
  • chronic neurological disease: (e.g. Stroke/TIAs)
  • diabetes mellitus (including diet controlled)
  • immunosuppression due to disease or treatment (e.g. HIV)
  • asplenia or splenic dysfunction
  • pregnant women

Other at risk individuals include:
  • health and social care staff directly involved in patient care (e.g. NHS staff)
  • those living in long-stay residential care homes
  • carers of the elderly or disabled person whose welfare may be at risk if the carer becomes ill (at the GP's discretion)
The pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine is offered to all adults over the age of 65 years and those with:
  • asplenia or splenic dysfunction
  • chronic respiratory disease: COPD, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, interstitial lung disease. Asthma is only included if 'it requires the use of oral steroids at a dose sufficient to act as a significant immunosuppressant'
  • chronic heart disease: ischaemic heart disease if requiring medication or follow-up, heart failure, congenital heart disease. Controlled hypertension is not an indication for vaccination
  • chronic kidney disease (at stages 4 and 5, nephrotic syndrome, kidney transplantation)
  • chronic liver disease: including cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis
  • diabetes mellitus if requiring medication
  • immunosuppression (either due to disease or treatment). This includes patients with any stage of HIV infection
  • cochlear implants
  • patients with cerebrospinal fluid leaks
concept: The pneumococcal vaccine should be offered to patients with chronic hepatitis
links:
Green book48
Pneumococcal


Green book44
Influenza

3183.concept_text: The pneumococcal vaccine should be offered to patients with chronic hepatitis

questions:
A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of palpitations. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath and has otherwise been well in himself. His past medical history includes ischaemic heart disease and had a PCI to the left circumflex artery 3 years ago. He is an ex-smoker.

On examination, his heart rate is 140 beats/min and regular with a blood pressure of 133/69mmHg. Auscultation of his chest is clear with oxygen saturations of 94% on room air. His GCS is 15/15.

ECG: Monomorphic regular tachycardia, QRS duration 150ms.

What is the most appropriate management?
notes:
Amiodarone is correct. This patient has a regular broad-complex tachycardia given the heart rate of 140 beats/min and QRS duration > 120ms. Given the history of ischaemic heart disease and the presence of a monomorphic wave pattern, the underlying rhythm is most likely in keeping with ventricular tachycardia. In the management of a tachyarrhythmia, it is important to establish the presence of any adverse features including ischaemia, syncope, shock or heart failure. In the absence of these, pharmacological cardioversion with amiodarone can be commenced.

Adenosine is incorrect. This is used in the management of supraventricular tachycardia; a narrow complex tachycardia (QRS < 120ms) that is commonly associated with alcohol, illicit drug or caffeine use.

DC cardioversion is incorrect. This patient does not have any adverse features (ischaemia, syncope, shock or heart failure) and, therefore, does not require DC cardioversion.

Magnesium sulphate is incorrect. This is used in the management of Torsades de Pointes which is commonly described as a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with a prolonged QTc interval. This is not in keeping with this patient's presentation.

Metoprolol is incorrect. Although this beta-blocker may slow down the heart rate, metoprolol will play no role in the cardioversion of this patient to sinus rhythm and, therefore, is not indicated.

Metoprolol is incorrect. Although this beta-blocker may slow down the heart rate, metoprolol will play no role in the cardioversion of this patient to sinus rhythm and, therefore, is not indicated.
title: Peri-arrest rhythms: tachycardia
body:
The 2015 Resuscitation Council (UK) guidelines have simplified the advice given for the management of peri-arrest tachycardias. Separate algorithms for the management of broad-complex tachycardia, narrow complex tachycardia and atrial fibrillation have been replaced by one unified treatment algorithm

Following basic ABC assessment, patients are classified as being stable or unstable according to the presence of any adverse signs:
  • shock: hypotension (systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg), pallor, sweating, cold, clammy extremities, confusion or impaired consciousness
  • syncope
  • myocardial ischaemia
  • heart failure

If any of the above adverse signs are present then synchronised DC shocks should be given. Up to 3 shocks can be given; after this expert help should be sought.

Treatment following this is given according to whether the QRS complex is narrow or broad and whether the rhythm is regular or irregular. The full treatment guidelines can be found at the Resuscitation Council website, below is a very limited summary:


Broad-complex tachycardia

Regular
  • assume ventricular tachycardia (unless previously confirmed SVT with bundle branch block)
  • loading dose of amiodarone followed by 24 hour infusion

Irregular
  • seek expert help. Possibilities include:
    • atrial fibrillation with bundle branch block - the most likely cause in a stable patient
    • atrial fibrillation with ventricular pre-excitation
    • torsade de pointes


Narrow-complex tachycardia

Regular
  • vagal manoeuvres followed by IV adenosine
  • if the above is unsuccessful consider a diagnosis of atrial flutter and control rate (e.g. beta-blockers)

Irregular
  • probable atrial fibrillation
  • if onset < 48 hr consider electrical or chemical cardioversion
  • rate control: beta-blockers are usually first-line unless there is a contraindication
concept: IV amiodarone is the first-line treatment for regular broad complex tachycardias without adverse features
links:
Resuscitation Council UK2912
2021 Tachycardia algorithm
media:
Intro to EKG Interpretation - Practicing Tachyarrhythmia Identification
Strong Medicine - YouTube41
 
Arrhythmia Overview - Mechanism of bradyarrhythmia and tachyarrhythmia
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube41
 
Intro to EKG Interpretation - How to Identify Any Tachyarrhythmia with 6 Easy Questions
Strong Medicine - YouTube41
 
Intro to EKG Interpretation - Overview of Tachyarrhythmias
Strong Medicine - YouTube72
 
Intro to EKG Interpretation - Mechanisms of Tachyarrhythmias
Strong Medicine - YouTube22

5236.concept_text: Patients with tachycardia and signs of shock, syncope, myocardial ischaemia or heart failure should receive up to 3 synchronised DC shocks

10903.concept_text: In the context of a tachyarrhythmia, a systolic BP < 90 mmHg --> DC cardioversion

11312.concept_text: IV amiodarone is the first-line treatment for regular broad complex tachycardias without adverse features

options: Advise her of the risks and the need to keep away from anyone who has rubella
Discuss the risks of congenital rubella syndrome and counsel regarding a termination of pregnancy
Advise monthly rubella IgM checks + avoid infectious contacts
Advise weekly human normal immunoglobulin injections until > 20 weeks gestation + avoid infectious contacts
questions:
You review the blood results taken from a pregnant woman at her booking visit. In addition to the standard antenatal bloods she also had her rubella status checked as she didn't have the MMR vaccine as a child. She is now 11 weeks pregnant and currently well.

Rubella IgGNOT detected

What is the most appropriate course of action?
notes: This scenario is now rare due to the widespread uptake of the MMR vaccination. It does however still occur, particularly in immigrant communities.
question:
You review the blood results taken from a pregnant woman at her booking visit. In addition to the standard antenatal bloods she also had her rubella status checked as she didn't have the MMR vaccine as a child. She is now 11 weeks pregnant and currently well.

Rubella IgGNOT detected

What is the most appropriate course of action?
question_notes: This scenario is now rare due to the widespread uptake of the MMR vaccination. It does however still occur, particularly in immigrant communities.
title: Rubella and pregnancy
body:
Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection caused by the togavirus. Following the introduction of the MMR vaccine it is now rare. If contracted during pregnancy there is a risk of congenital rubella syndrome. Remember that the incubation period is 14-21 days and individuals are infectious from 7 days before symptoms appear to 4 days after the onset of the rash.

Risk
  • in first 8-10 weeks risk of damage to fetus is as high as 90%
  • damage is rare after 16 weeks

Features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • sensorineural deafness
  • congenital cataracts
  • congenital heart disease (e.g. patent ductus arteriosus)
  • growth retardation
  • hepatosplenomegaly
  • purpuric skin lesions
  • 'salt and pepper' chorioretinitis
  • microphthalmia
  • cerebral palsy

Diagnosis
  • suspected cases should be discussed immediately with the local Health Protection Unit (HPU) as type/timing of investigations may vary
  • IgM antibodies are raised in women recently exposed to the virus
  • it should be noted that it is very difficult to distinguish rubella from parvovirus B19 clinically. It is therefore important to also check parvovirus B19 serology as there is a 30% risk of transplacental infection, with a 5-10% risk of fetal loss

Management
  • suspected cases of rubella in pregnancy should be discussed with the local Health Protection Unit
  • since 2016, rubella immunity is no longer routinely checked at the booking visit
  • if a woman is however tested at any point and no immunity is demonstrated they should be advised to keep away from people who might have rubella
  • non-immune mothers should be offered the MMR vaccination in the post-natal period
    • MMR vaccines should not be administered to women known to be pregnant or attempting to become pregnant

2957.concept_text: If a pregnant woman is not immune to rubella, she should be offered the MMR vaccination in the post-natal period

questions: A 60-year-old homeless lady is brought into the emergency department by the paramedics. They have found her unconscious and an ECG shows a broad complex polymorphic tachycardia indicative of torsades de pointes.  Which of the following could be a cause of this woman's arrhythmia?
notes:
This question is asking about a patient presenting with a broad complex polymorphic tachycardia. This is characteristic of torsades de pointes. Therefore the correct answer is hypothermia, which is a known cause.

Hypocalcaemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesaemia are all causes of torsades de pointes and not their hyper counterparts listed above.

There is no link between hypoglycemia or hyperthyroidism and Torsades de Pointes
question: A 60-year-old homeless lady is brought into the emergency department by the paramedics. They have found her unconscious and an ECG shows a broad complex polymorphic tachycardia indicative of torsades de pointes.  Which of the following could be a cause of this woman's arrhythmia?
question_notes:
This question is asking about a patient presenting with a broad complex polymorphic tachycardia. This is characteristic of torsades de pointes. Therefore the correct answer is hypothermia, which is a known cause.

Hypocalcaemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesaemia are all causes of torsades de pointes and not their hyper counterparts listed above.

There is no link between hypoglycemia or hyperthyroidism and Torsades de Pointes
title: Torsades de pointes
body:
Torsades de pointes ('twisting of the points') is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with a long QT interval. It may deteriorate into ventricular fibrillation and hence lead to sudden death.

Causes of long QT interval
  • congenital
    • Jervell-Lange-Nielsen syndrome
    • Romano-Ward syndrome
  • antiarrhythmics: amiodarone, sotalol, class 1a antiarrhythmic drugs
  • tricyclic antidepressants
  • antipsychotics
  • chloroquine
  • terfenadine
  • erythromycin
  • electrolyte: hypocalcaemia, hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia
  • myocarditis
  • hypothermia
  • subarachnoid haemorrhage

Management
  • IV magnesium sulphate

© Image used on license from Dr Smith, University of Minnesota
ECG showing torsades de pointes
concept: Hypothermia is a cause of Torsades de pointes
links:
Life in the Fast Lane286
Torsades de pointes
media:
Long QT syndrome & torsade de pointes
Osmosis - YouTube31

3643.concept_text: Hypothermia is a cause of Torsades de pointes

4928.concept_text: IV magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de pointes

6003.concept_text: Macrolides can cause torsades de pointes

questions:
A 23-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant presents with a rapidly growing lesion on her finger. This has grown from the size of a 'pin-prick' when it first appeared 4 weeks ago.

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is a Pyogenic granuloma. Pyogenic granulomas are benign, vascular skin lesions that grow rapidly over weeks or months. They can occur at any age but are more common in children and young adults, particularly pregnant women due to hormonal changes. The lesion often appears as a small, red, raised bump that may bleed easily. In this case, the rapid growth of the lesion and the patient's pregnancy status make pyogenic granuloma the most likely diagnosis.

A Viral wart is less likely because these typically grow slowly over time rather than rapidly. Moreover, they usually have a rough surface whereas the lesion in question appears smooth.

Orf is an infectious disease caused by a parapoxvirus affecting sheep and goats. Humans can contract it through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated objects. However, it usually presents as one or few lesions on hands or fingers with surrounding erythema and regional lymphadenopathy which does not seem to be the case here.

A Capillary haemangioma, also known as strawberry naevus, commonly occurs in infants and usually regresses spontaneously by childhood. It would be rare for it to first appear in an adult woman.

Finally, Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is unlikely given the patient's age - SCC typically occurs in older individuals who have had significant sun exposure over their lifetime. Furthermore, SCCs generally grow slowly over time rather than rapidly.

However, it usually presents as one or few lesions on hands or fingers with surrounding erythema and regional lymphadenopathy which does not seem to be the case here.

title: Pyogenic granuloma
body:
Pyogenic granuloma is a relatively common benign skin lesion. The name is confusing as they are neither true granulomas nor pyogenic in nature. There are multiple alternative names but perhaps 'eruptive haemangioma' is the most useful.

The cause of pyogenic granuloma is not known but a number of factors are linked:
  • trauma
  • pregnancy
  • more common in women and young adults

Features
  • most common sites are head/neck, upper trunk and hands. Lesions in the oral mucosa are common in pregnancy
  • initially small red/brown spot
  • rapidly progress within days to weeks forming raised, red/brown lesions which are often spherical in shape
  • the lesions may bleed profusely or ulcerate


Management
  • lesions associated with pregnancy often resolve spontaneously post-partum
  • other lesions usually persist. Removal methods include curettage and cauterisation, cryotherapy, excision
links:
DermNet NZ143
Pyogenic granuloma

questions: A woman consults you regarding skin lesions on her chest. On examination there are two similar lesions, each a tiny red papule with visible fine vessels surrounding it. The lesions blanch on pressure. Which common medication may be responsible for the lesions?
notes: This is a description of spider naevi, a type of skin angioma found in the distribution of the superior vena cava.  They can occur spontaneously, but multiple lesions are abnormal and may indicate excess oestrogen - typically due to liver cirrhosis (as the liver processes oestrogens), but also sometimes in response to pregnancy or oestrogen-containing medications.
question: A woman consults you regarding skin lesions on her chest. On examination there are two similar lesions, each a tiny red papule with visible fine vessels surrounding it. The lesions blanch on pressure. Which common medication may be responsible for the lesions?
question_notes: This is a description of spider naevi, a type of skin angioma found in the distribution of the superior vena cava.  They can occur spontaneously, but multiple lesions are abnormal and may indicate excess oestrogen - typically due to liver cirrhosis (as the liver processes oestrogens), but also sometimes in response to pregnancy or oestrogen-containing medications.
title: Spider naevi
body:
Spider naevi (also called spider angiomas) describe a central red papule with surrounding capillaries. The lesions blanch upon pressure. Spider naevi are almost always found on the upper part of the body.

Spider naevi can be differentiated from telangiectasia by pressing on them and watching them fill. Spider naevi fill from the centre, telangiectasia from the edge .

Around 10-15% of people will have one or more spider naevi and they are more common in childhood. Other associations
  • liver disease
  • pregnancy
  • combined oral contraceptive pill

4527.concept_text: Spider naevi can be differentiated from telangiectasia by pressing on them and watching them fill. Spider naevi fill from the centre, telangiectasia from the edge

questions:
A 50-year-old Afro-Caribbean male patient presents to the GP surgery with lumps on both sides of the face. He also reports a 6-months history of a dry cough with some night sweats. On examination, there is painless enlargement of both parotid glands. He is otherwise fit and well.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
In view of a dry cough and bilateral parotid swellings, the patient is likely to have sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a cause of bilateral parotid swellings.

Parotid tumours are usually unilateral.

Mumps causes painful parotid enlargement and would not cause 6 months of a dry cough.

Lyme disease does not usually cause parotid swellings.

Sjogren's syndrome is a cause of bilateral parotid swellings but does not usually cause pulmonary symptoms
question:
A 50-year-old Afro-Caribbean male patient presents to the GP surgery with lumps on both sides of the face. He also reports a 6-months history of a dry cough with some night sweats. On examination, there is painless enlargement of both parotid glands. He is otherwise fit and well.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes:
In view of a dry cough and bilateral parotid swellings, the patient is likely to have sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a cause of bilateral parotid swellings.

Parotid tumours are usually unilateral.

Mumps causes painful parotid enlargement and would not cause 6 months of a dry cough.

Lyme disease does not usually cause parotid swellings.

Sjogren's syndrome is a cause of bilateral parotid swellings but does not usually cause pulmonary symptoms
title: Parotid gland swelling
body:
Swelling of this gland is either unilateral or bilateral. Disorders of the gland cause swelling and pain which may be pronounced on eating or talking. There may be associated fever and a foul taste in the mouth.

Bilateral causes
  • viruses: mumps
  • sarcoidosis
  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • lymphoma
  • alcoholic liver disease

Unilateral causes
  • tumour: pleomorphic adenomas
  • stones
  • infection
concept: Sarcoidosis is a cause of bilateral parotid swellings

options: Urgent hip referral for hip CT scan
Urgent hip referral for hip x-ray
questions: You are a foundation doctor on the postnatal ward. You perform a newborn examination on a one-day-old baby boy. He was born in good condition by normal vaginal delivery. When examining the hips you are concerned that you are able to relocate a dislocated left hip. What is the appropriate management step?
notes:
This baby has a clearly abnormal ortolani manoeuvre which requires urgent assessment to identify potential developmental dysplasia of the hip. Ultrasound is the most appropriate imaging, avoiding radiation and giving the best visualisation of the developing hip.

Routine referral would cause unnecessary delay to this child's treatment and reassurance would be inappropriate given the clearly abnormal screening test.
question: You are a foundation doctor on the postnatal ward. You perform a newborn examination on a one-day-old baby boy. He was born in good condition by normal vaginal delivery. When examining the hips you are concerned that you are able to relocate a dislocated left hip. What is the appropriate management step?
question_notes:
This baby has a clearly abnormal ortolani manoeuvre which requires urgent assessment to identify potential developmental dysplasia of the hip. Ultrasound is the most appropriate imaging, avoiding radiation and giving the best visualisation of the developing hip.

Routine referral would cause unnecessary delay to this child's treatment and reassurance would be inappropriate given the clearly abnormal screening test.
title: Developmental dysplasia of the hip
body:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is gradually replacing the old term 'congenital dislocation of the hip' (CDH). It affects around 1-3% of newborns.

Risk factors
  • female sex: 6 times greater risk
  • breech presentation
  • positive family history
  • firstborn children
  • oligohydramnios
  • birth weight > 5 kg
  • congenital calcaneovalgus foot deformity

DDH is slightly more common in the left hip. Around 20% of cases are bilateral.

Screening for DDH
  • the following infants require a routine ultrasound examination
    • first-degree family history of hip problems in early life
    • breech presentation at or after 36 weeks gestation, irrespective of presentation at birth or mode of delivery
    • multiple pregnancy
  • all infants are screened at both the newborn check and also the six-week baby check using the Barlow and Ortolani tests

Clinical examination
  • Barlow test: attempts to dislocate an articulated femoral head
  • Ortolani test: attempts to relocate a dislocated femoral head
  • other important factors include:
    • symmetry of leg length
    • level of knees when hips and knees are bilaterally flexed
    • restricted abduction of the hip in flexion

Imaging
  • ultrasound is generally used to confirm the diagnosis if clinically suspected
  • however, if the infant is > 4.5 months then x-ray is the first line investigation

Management
  • most unstable hips will spontaneously stabilise by 3-6 weeks of age
  • Pavlik harness (dynamic flexion-abduction orthosis) in children younger than 4-5 months
  • older children may require surgery
concept: Ortolani manoeuvre: attempted relocation of a newborn's femoral head after dislocation due to the Barlow manoeuvre
links:
Publich Health England107
2019 Newborn and infant physical examination (NIPE) screening programme handbook
media:
Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)
Scientific Animations Without Borders - YouTube254
 
Congenital hip dysplasia
Osmosis - YouTube92

3069.concept_text: Barlow manoeuvre: attempted dislocation of a newborns femoral head

3070.concept_text: Ortolani manoeuvre: attempted relocation of a newborn's femoral head after dislocation due to the Barlow manoeuvre

4234.concept_text: All breech babies at or after 36 weeks gestation require USS for DDH screening at 6 weeks regardless of mode of delivery

10583.concept_text: Breech presentation is a risk factor for developmental dysplasia of the hip

theme: First trimester bleeding at 7 weeks gestation management
options: Repeat urine pregnancy test in 7-10 days
questions:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with vaginal bleeding. She has a positive home pregnancy test and her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She denies abdominal pain. Examination reveals minimal vaginal bleeding with a closed cervical os and no cervical motion tenderness.

Select the single most appropriate next step from the options below.
notes:
Arrange transvaginal ultrasound scan is the correct answer. According to NICE guidelines on ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage (2019), women presenting with bleeding at greater than 6 weeks gestation should be referred to an early pregnancy assessment service for investigation. A transvaginal ultrasound scan is the most important investigation in this scenario as it can identify the location of the pregnancy (intrauterine versus ectopic), determine viability by detecting a fetal pole and heartbeat, and assess for signs of miscarriage. At 7 weeks gestation, a transvaginal scan should be able to visualise an intrauterine gestational sac with a yolk sac and possibly a fetal pole with cardiac activity. This investigation is crucial for distinguishing between viable pregnancy, miscarriage, and ectopic pregnancy, which guides subsequent management. Even in the absence of pain, ectopic pregnancy remains in the differential diagnosis and must be excluded, making imaging essential rather than expectant management.

Measure serum beta-hCG level may provide supportive information but is not the most appropriate next step. Whilst beta-hCG levels can help assess pregnancy viability when correlated with ultrasound findings or when serial measurements show appropriate rise or fall, they do not provide definitive information about pregnancy location or viability. A single beta-hCG measurement has limited diagnostic value in isolation. The priority in a woman at 7 weeks gestation with bleeding is to visualise the pregnancy directly with ultrasound to exclude ectopic pregnancy and assess viability, rather than relying on biochemical markers which may delay definitive diagnosis.

Repeat urine pregnancy test in 7-10 days would be inappropriate at this gestation. This expectant approach is only suitable for women who are less than 6 weeks pregnant with bleeding but no pain or risk factors for ectopic pregnancy. This patient is 7 weeks gestation, which mandates referral for assessment and ultrasound scanning according to NICE guidelines. Delaying investigation could miss an ectopic pregnancy or other significant pathology requiring intervention.

Arrange transabdominal ultrasound scan is less appropriate than transvaginal scanning in early pregnancy. Transabdominal ultrasound has lower sensitivity and resolution in the first trimester compared to the transvaginal approach. At 7 weeks gestation, structures may not be adequately visualised transabdominally, particularly in women with higher body mass index or retroverted uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound is the gold standard investigation for early pregnancy complications as it provides superior visualisation of early gestational structures.

Measure serum progesterone level has limited clinical utility in this scenario. Whilst low progesterone levels may be associated with non-viable pregnancies, there is significant overlap between viable and non-viable pregnancies, making it an unreliable diagnostic tool. Progesterone measurement does not help localise the pregnancy or distinguish between intrauterine and ectopic pregnancy. Current NICE guidelines do not recommend routine progesterone measurement in the assessment of early pregnancy bleeding, as direct visualisation with ultrasound provides more definitive diagnostic information.

Repeat urine pregnancy test in 7-10 days would be inappropriate at this gestation. This expectant approach is only suitable for women who are less than 6 weeks pregnant with bleeding but no pain or risk factors for ectopic pregnancy. This patient is 7 weeks gestation, which mandates referral for assessment and ultrasound scanning according to NICE guidelines. Delaying investigation could miss an ectopic pregnancy or other significant pathology requiring intervention.

Arrange transabdominal ultrasound scan is less appropriate than transvaginal scanning in early pregnancy. Transabdominal ultrasound has lower sensitivity and resolution in the first trimester compared to the transvaginal approach. At 7 weeks gestation, structures may not be adequately visualised transabdominally, particularly in women with higher body mass index or retroverted uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound is the gold standard investigation for early pregnancy complications as it provides superior visualisation of early gestational structures.

Measure serum progesterone level has limited clinical utility in this scenario. Whilst low progesterone levels may be associated with non-viable pregnancies, there is significant overlap between viable and non-viable pregnancies, making it an unreliable diagnostic tool. Progesterone measurement does not help localise the pregnancy or distinguish between intrauterine and ectopic pregnancy. Current NICE guidelines do not recommend routine progesterone measurement in the assessment of early pregnancy bleeding, as direct visualisation with ultrasound provides more definitive diagnostic information.
title: Bleeding in the first trimester
body:
Bleeding in the first trimester is a common reason women in early pregnancy seek medical attention.

The main differential diagnosis is as follows:
  • miscarriage
  • ectopic pregnancy
    • the most 'important' cause as missed ectopics can be potentially life-threatening
  • implantation bleeding
    • a diagnosis of exclusion
  • miscellaneous conditions
    • cervical ectropion
    • vaginitis
    • trauma
    • polyps

NICE released guidelines on the management of ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage in 2019. In these guidelines they discussed how to manage early bleeding:

Worrying symptoms suggestive of an ectopic

If a woman has a positive pregnancy test and any of the following she should be referred immediately to an early pregnancy assessment service:
  • pain and abdominal tenderness
  • pelvic tenderness
  • cervical motion tenderness

>= 6 weeks gestation

If the pregnancy is > 6 weeks gestation (or of uncertain gestation) and the woman has bleeding she should be referred to an early pregnancy assessment service.

A transvaginal ultrasound scan is the most important investigation to identify the location of the pregnancy and whether there is a fetal pole and heartbeat.

< 6 weeks gestation

If the pregnancy is < 6 weeks gestation and women have bleeding, but NO pain or risk factors for ectopic pregnancy, then they can be managed expectantly. These women should be advised:
  • to return if bleeding continues or pain develops
  • to repeat a urine pregnancy test after 7-10 days and to return if it is positive
  • a negative pregnancy test means that the pregnancy has miscarried
concept: Bleeding in the first trimester: a transvaginal ultrasound scan is the most important investigation
links:
NICE31
2023 Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: diagnosis and initial management

11956.concept_text: Bleeding in the first trimester: a transvaginal ultrasound scan is the most important investigation

questions:
A 58-year-old woman reports that for the past 1 year she has found that having sex with her husband has become increasingly painful. She denies any discharge but says that her vagina often feels dry and sore. She has tried using vaginal moisturisers and lubricants which she believes have slightly eased the soreness.

On examination the vagina appears pale and dry.

Given the likely diagnosis which one of the following is the most suitable treatment method?
notes: Atrophic vaginitis often occurs in women who are post-menopausal women. It presents with vaginal dryness, dyspareunia and occasional spotting. On examination the vagina may appear pale and dry. Treatment is with vaginal lubricants and moisturisers, if these do not help then topical oestrogen cream can be used.

title: Atrophic vaginitis
body: Atrophic vaginitis often occurs in women who are post-menopausal women. It presents with vaginal dryness, dyspareunia and occasional spotting. On examination, the vagina may appear pale and dry. Treatment is with vaginal lubricants and moisturisers -  if these do not help then topical oestrogen cream can be used.
